question.title: Neat way of doing stuff with a List (and such) in Java

node.contents: In C# you can do some operations on a list, like this:

astNode.text: In C# you can do some operations on a list, like this:

node.contents: This returns the average of all values. Is there something similar in Java? (That would save me the calculation of a sum and then division by the number of elements?)

astNode.text: This returns the average of all values. Is there something similar in Java? (That would save me the calculation of a sum and then division by the number of elements?)

node.contents: I wouldn't use `float` esp when your values are `double`.

astNode.text: I wouldn't use `float` esp when your values are `double`.

node.contents: Good point @Peter Lawrey. Edited the response to return a Double instead.

astNode.text: Good point @Peter Lawrey. Edited the response to return a Double instead.

node.contents: I wouldn't use `Double` either, unless you want to allow a `null` value. `double` is much more efficent and more concise.

astNode.text: I wouldn't use `Double` either, unless you want to allow a `null` value. `double` is much more efficent and more concise.

node.contents: It depends on the type of collection you are creating. I don't think the native java Array types support any functionality like this. However there are other collections that can do these sorts of things, for example Apache Commons Math has a number of structures to do just this sort of thing. Guava is another package with a lot of great Array methods built in.

astNode.text: It depends on the type of collection you are creating. I don't think the native java Array types support any functionality like this. However there are other collections that can do these sorts of things, for example Apache Commons Math has a number of structures to do just this sort of thing. Guava is another package with a lot of great Array methods built in.

node.contents: Another option one could easily implement would be to extend the collection your using. For example:

astNode.text: Another option one could easily implement would be to extend the collection your using. For example:

elements.contents: public class ArrayListExtension extends ArrayList{ public ArrayListExtension(){} public Double average() { Double sum = 0; Iterator<Double> iterator = this.iterator(); while(iterator.hasNext()){ sum += iterator.next(); } return sum/this.size(); } }

units.rawText: public class ArrayListExtension extends ArrayList{ public ArrayListExtension(){} public Double average() { Double sum = 0; Iterator<Double> iterator = this.iterator(); while(iterator.hasNext()){ sum += iterator.next(); } return sum/this.size(); } }

node.contents: Note: There are no sanity checks built into this. In a real-world implementation you'd want to do some try-catch to make sure that the values are actual numbers.

astNode.text: Note: There are no sanity checks built into this. In a real-world implementation you'd want to do some try-catch to make sure that the values are actual numbers.

elements.contents: Double totalAge = sumFrom(persons).getAge(); //Divide by size to get Average

units.rawText: Double totalAge = sumFrom(persons).getAge(); //Divide by size to get Average

node.contents: You can do the following to get the average of some numbers. Unless you do this lot, there isn't much saving.

astNode.text: You can do the following to get the average of some numbers. Unless you do this lot, there isn't much saving.

elements.contents: public static double average(Collection<Number> coll) { double total = 0; for(Number n: coll) total += n.doubleValue(); return total/coll.size(); }

units.rawText: public static double average(Collection<Number> coll) { double total = 0; for(Number n: coll) total += n.doubleValue(); return total/coll.size(); }

node.contents: it would take quite a hack to do this via function and transform (transform is meant to transform n values of one type into n values of another, not collect a common value). How about a code example?

astNode.text: it would take quite a hack to do this via function and transform (transform is meant to transform n values of one type into n values of another, not collect a common value). How about a code example?

node.contents: No but you could use guava-libraries Function and transform to achieve the same. Here is an example

astNode.text: No but you could use guava-libraries Function and transform to achieve the same. Here is an example

node.contents: You can use Lists.transform(...) as well. It will apply the function to the same elements (no copies are created).

astNode.text: You can use Lists.transform(...) as well. It will apply the function to the same elements (no copies are created).

node.contents: Here is a safe version of Peter Lawrey's answer, using BigDecimal:

astNode.text: Here is a safe version of Peter Lawrey's answer, using BigDecimal:

elements.contents: public static double safeAverage(final Collection<? extends Number> coll){ BigDecimal dec = BigDecimal.ZERO; for(final Number n : coll){ dec = dec.add(BigDecimal.valueOf(n.doubleValue())); } return dec.divide(BigDecimal.valueOf(coll.size())).doubleValue(); }

units.rawText: public static double safeAverage(final Collection<? extends Number> coll){ BigDecimal dec = BigDecimal.ZERO; for(final Number n : coll){ dec = dec.add(BigDecimal.valueOf(n.doubleValue())); } return dec.divide(BigDecimal.valueOf(coll.size())).doubleValue(); }

node.contents: (Not quite safe, however, as BigInteger and BigDecimal also extend Number. Safe if used with any of the Number implementations in java.lang)

astNode.text: (Not quite safe, however, as BigInteger and BigDecimal also extend Number. Safe if used with any of the Number implementations in java.lang)
